chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Assessing the type of urinary incontinence
Assessing for underlying causes and contributing factors
Assessing the severity of urinary incontinence

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the cautions and contraindications for duloxetine?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not prescribe duloxetine to people aged under 18 years, or people with:
    • Hepatic impairment.
    • Severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance less than 30 mL/min).
    • Uncontrolled hypertension.
  • Prescribe duloxetine with caution to people with:
    • A history of bleeding disorders.
    • A history of seizures.
    • A history of mania or bipolar disorder.
    • Cardiac disease.
    • Hypertension.
    • Susceptibility to angle-closure glaucoma, or raised intraocular pressure.
    • Susceptibility to hyponatraemia.
  • Also prescribe with caution in elderly people.

[ABPI, 2019f; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What dose of duloxetine should I prescribe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For the management of symptoms of stress urinary incontinence:
    • The recommended dose of duloxetine is 40 mg taken twice a day.
    • Re-assess after 2–4 weeks of treatment to evaluate the benefit and tolerability of the treatment.
  • If adverse effects are likely to be a problem, consider starting treatment at a dosage of 20 mg twice a day for 2 weeks before increasing to the recommended dosage of 40 mg twice a day.
  • For information on treatment reduction and discontinuation, see the section on Drug withdrawal or dose reduction.

[ABPI, 2019f; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What issues should I consider when withdrawing or reducing the dose of duloxetine?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person not to stop treatment abruptly.
  • If duloxetine treatment is to be discontinued, reduce the dose gradually over at least 1 to 2 weeks to reduce the risk of withdrawal reactions.
  • If intolerable withdrawal reactions occur after a dose reduction or on stopping treatment, resume the previously prescribed dose and continue decreasing the dose more gradually.

[ABPI, 2019f]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions with duloxetine?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Drug interactions with duloxetine include:
    • Aspirin, NSAIDs, and antiplatelets — increased risk of bleeding if taken concomitantly with duloxetine.
    • Drugs metabolised by CYP2D6 (for example risperidone, tricyclic antidepressants, flecainide, metoprolol) — duloxetine is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6. 
    • Ciprofloxacin — may increase levels of duloxetine. Concurrent use is contraindicated.
    • Anticoagulants — duloxetine possibly enhances the anticoagulant effect of warfarin. Use with caution or avoid.
    • Other sedative drugs (for example antipsychotics, benzodiazepines, sedative antihistamines) — use caution if considering concurrent use of duloxetine and other centrally acting drugs.
  • Serotonin syndrome may occur with duloxetine, particularly if the person is also taking other serotonergic agents, drugs that impair the metabolism of serotonin, or antipsychotic drugs or dopamine antagonists that may affect serotonergic neurotransmitter systems. These include:
    • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) — concurrent use is contraindicated. 
    • SSRIs. 
    • SNRIs.
    • Tricyclic antidepressants.
    • Triptans. 

[ABPI, 2019f; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What adverse effects of duloxetine should I be aware of?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The most common adverse effects seen in clinical trials of duloxetine for stress urinary incontinence and other lower urinary tract disorders were nausea, dry mouth, fatigue, and constipation. Other adverse effects include:

  • Cardiac — palpitation; tachycardia, supraventricular arrhythmia (rare).
  • Gastrointestinal (GI) —  vomiting, diarrhoea, dyspepsia, abdominal pain (common); gastrointestinal haemorrhage, gastroenteritis, dysphagia, flatulence (uncommon).
    • Rarely: microscopic colitis.
  • Nervous system — headache, somnolence; dizziness, lethargy, tremor, paraesthesia (common); nervousness, akathisia, myoclonus, dyskinesia (uncommon/rare).
    • Rarely: serotonin syndrome, convulsions, psychomotor restlessness, extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Psychiatric — insomnia, anxiety, agitation, sleep disorder (common); abnormal dreams, disorientation (uncommon).
    • Rarely: suicidal thoughts/behaviour, mania, hallucinations, aggression, anger.
  • Skin and subcutaneous tissue — increased sweating (common); rash, urticaria, dermatitis, (uncommon).
    • Rarely: Stevens-Johnson syndrome, photosensitivity, angioneurotic oedema.
  • Also:
    • Blood pressure increases, flushing.
    • Blurred vision.
    • Cholesterol level increases.
    • Decreased appetite.
    • Sexual dysfunction.
    • Hepatitis.
    • Hyponatraemia, syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). 
    • Tinnitus.
    • Urinary problems.
    • Yawning.

[ABPI, 2019f; Joint Formulary Committee, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What monitoring is required for duloxetine?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• In people with hypertension or other cardiac disease, monitor blood pressure, especially during the first month.
    • If a sustained increase in BP occurs, consider either a dose reduction or a gradual discontinuation of duloxetine.

[ABPI, 2019f]
